Dimension of the Column Space or Rank

The following is adapted from Khanacademy

Rank is the dimension of the basis of a matrix.

In order to be a basis, it has to satisfy that

  • vectors span

  • all the column vectors of a basis are linear independent

for example

(1)

the column space of is

(2)

However, we don’t know if all the column vectors in the span are linear independant

To find the basis, let’s convert to reduced echelon form

(3)

let denote the columns of A

(4)

we see that are linear independent and for the basis of , and the 1s in these column vectors are also called the pivot entries. Moreover, can be represented as linear combinations of

Therefore, we can conclude that are also linear independent and they are the basis of

And the Rank of A is just the dimension of the basis, so

Linear subspaces

In order to be a subspace, a set must satisfy the following 3 criterias

let

Let’s assume is a subspace of

then

1:

2:

And if This is defined as closure under scalar multiplication

3:

This is defined as closure under addition

a trival example in

it satisifies the 3 criterias

1: it contains the zero vector.

2: when it is multiplied by any real number scalar c, it is still itself. This implies it is still a member of and satisify closure under multiplication

3: when , this implies it satisifies closure under addition

so it is a subspace.
